comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# OQS-wireshark
+
+This docker image contains a version of [wireshark](https://www.wireshark.org/) built to also properly display quantum-safe crypto (QSC) TLS operations.
+
+To this end, it contains references to algorithms supported by [liboqs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs) and [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl) from the [OpenQuantumSafe](https://openquantumsafe.org) project.
+
+The image is based on Ubuntu and requires the host to run the Unix X-Window system.
+
+## Quick start
+
+Execute this command to open the wireshark window on your host:
+
+    docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
+
+*Note:* Select a network interface to monitor.
+
+## Suggested test
+
+At https://test.openquantumsafe.org most quantum-safe algorithms that are still part of the NIST PQC competition are available for TLS interoperability testing.
+
+As a client, we recommend using an OQS-enabled `curl` docker image that may be executed for a quick initial test as follows:
+
+     docker run -it openquantumsafe/curl sh -c "curl -k https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6120 --curves p521_frodo1344aes"
+
+For more details regarding the client-side options, we recommend reviewing https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/openquantumsafe/curl
+
+### Focus on quantum-safe data traffic 
+
+In order to focus `wireshark` on the quantum safe TLS traffic generated by the above `curl` command, we recommend setting a wireshark display filter as follows
+
+     ip.addr == 149.81.106.123

pull_request.title: Wireshark
pull_request.body:
Building on https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/pull/104 (thanks to @anhu) this is an OQS-enabled wireshark build-and-dockerize command set. This will remain in draft status until documentation has been refined and final contents are agreed.

For a quick test/avoiding the need to build it locally, the image is available at docker hub under the name "openquantumsafe/wireshark", i.e., it can be executed (on X11-based UNIX hosts) via 

```
docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
```

All feedback welcome (tagging explicity @anhu @dstebila ) and suggesting to continue the discussion from #104 below.

@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# OQS-wireshark
+
+This docker image contains a version of [wireshark](https://www.wireshark.org/) built to also properly display quantum-safe crypto (QSC) TLS operations.
+
+To this end, it contains references to algorithms supported by [liboqs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs) and [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl) from the [OpenQuantumSafe](https://openquantumsafe.org) project.
+
+The image is based on Ubuntu and requires the host to run the Unix X-Window system.
+
+## Quick start
+
+Execute this command to open the wireshark window on your host:
+
+    docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
+
+*Note:* Select a network interface to monitor.
+
comment.body: That should not be necessary: The .Xauthority volume mount should do the same trick. But then again, different distributions may do things differently... So added. Thx.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+This directory contains a Dockerfile that builds wireshark that is patched to understand the OIDs and codepoints in TLS 1.3 that are supported by OQS-OpenSSL.
+
+## Quick start
+
+1) Be sure to have [docker installed](https://docs.docker.com/install).
+2) Run `docker build -t openquantumsafe/wireshark .` to create an QSC-enabled (codepoint and OID aware) wireshark docker image.
+
+## Usage
+
+Information how to use the image is [available in the separate file USAGE.md](USAGE.md).
+
comment.body: We so far only have a top-level contribution list (to which I added Anthony now) and think we should leave it at that in the interest of short README's if that's OK for you.

pull_request.title: Adding arm64_v8 optimized versions of saber.
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds arm optimized versions of lightsaber, firesaber, and saber from PQClean.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
This PR resolves: #1122, but looks like there is an issue with upstream where the frame pointer gets corrupted. (PQCLEAN: issue [#431](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/issues/431#issue-1059280939))
<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -44,6 +44,18 @@ parameter-sets:
     no-secret-dependent-branching-checked-by-valgrind: true
     large-stack-usage: false
     upstream: primary-upstream
+  - upstream-id: aarch64
+    supported-platforms:
+    - architecture: ARM64_V8
+      operating_systems:
+      - Linux
+      - Darwin
+    common-crypto:
+    - SHA3: liboqs
+    no-secret-dependent-branching-claimed: false
+    no-secret-dependent-branching-checked-by-valgrind: true
comment.body: How can it be that there's it is not claiming no-secret-dependent-branching but we're checking it anyway?

repo.name: liboqs

comment.body:
Yes it is. Since we don't advertise a minimum compiler version, Douglas suggested adding a compiler version check for the minimum version of gcc required to get access to the intrinsics we need. The modification in this PR allows (apple)clang to using the aarch64 optimized algorithms.

The reason the if statement doesn't check for "kyber" anymore is because these intrinsics appear in saber as well, so I made it more general.
